comments:
Almost every time I upgrade my Eclipse host, it ends up locking me out of my CVS
account. I speculate that what's happening is I launch the workspace at the
beginning of the day and don't pay any attention to it while I check my email,
browse bugs, etc. Meanwhile, the Synchronize view is probably repeatedly trying
to connect to the server and failing because it doesn't have my password.

So my guess is that:
(losing the password everytime Eclipse is upgraded) + (trying to connect before
prompting the user for a password) + (a user who's essentially not at the
computer) = locked CVS account

Do you know why CVS is trying to connect without an explict action on your 
part? Do you have a scheduled synchronize configured? If not, do you have 
change sets enabled?

As far as the failure goes, we ensure that only one connection is being 
attempted at a time and this connection should be blocked by the password 
prompt so that multiple attemps do not occur. Are multiple prompts visible 
when you return to Eclipse? Is there anything in the log file? Is this 
happening with dev.eclipse.org or another repository? 

As a workaround, you could either specify an alternate location for your 
keyring file (using the -keyring option when launchin Eclipse) or setup public 
key authentication (on the Team>CVS>SSH2 Connection Method preference page).

Yes, I have the Synch view scheduled to update periodically. I only see one
prompt when I come back to the workbench, but there are apparently more
connections being made than that because the account is already locked out when
I type my password the first time. Yes, I'm talking about the dev.eclipse.org
server. I pity the poor webmaster who has to keep unlocking my account. :-/

Within the past week, everyone at our lab (all three of us) has had their
accounts locked out. I've had it twice in the past week.

Could you attach your log file please. It may contain messages for each failed 
connection.
We found the hole and will provide a fix for M4.

Oof. Sorry for the slow reply, I had my log open and forgot to attach. I found

Actually, that is an interesting stack trace but is not related to the 
problem. The problem we found is that a connection fails silently with no 
prompting when Eclipse is not the active window. Once Eclipse becomes active, 
a prompt will occur but this will be after many failed attempts.

Fix released to HEAD. We now will never attempt a connection until sucessfully 
prompting after an initial connection fails.

Reopening. The fix for this is causing several other problems (bug 66885 and 
bug 81548). I'll need to look for an alternate solution. Downgrading seveity 
since the current fix works excepts for the above mentioned side affects.

I have released another fix that should prevent this. It will be in todays I 
build.
